title: What Windows 10 tools to back up bootable USB?

forumNotes.author: hemlatuyda
forumNotes.content: I need to backup my bootable USB stick because I have to format it. But I do need a complete dd-like 1:1 copy because I want it still to be bootable after recovery. I can only use Windows 10 for this. Which tools would be good?

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> I need to backup my bootable USB stick because I have to format it. But I do need a complete dd-like 1:1 copy because I want it still to be bootable after recovery. I can only use Windows 10 for this. Which tools would be good?

Clonedisk.

[http://labalec.fr/erwan/?page_id=42](http://labalec.fr/erwan/?page_id=42 "External link")

Or dd for windows.

[http://www.chrysocome.net/dd](http://www.chrysocome.net/dd "External link")

Or dsfok.

[http://members.ozema...eezip/freeware/](http://members.ozemail.com.au/~nulifetv/freezip/freeware/ "External link")

It has to be seen on Windows 10 if you need to set the disk offline to get access to the \\\\.\\Physicaldrive.

![:duff:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

forumNotes.author: hemlatuyda
forumNotes.content: Thanks, is there any tool that would actually have simple GUI for this kind of stuff? I've been told that win32diskimager could do it, but unsure if true.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Thanks, is there any tool that would actually have simple GUI for this kind of stuff? I've been told that win32diskimager could do it, but unsure if true.

Clonedisk is GUI, though admittedly not-so-simple.

But objectively:

dsf**o** \\\\.\\Physaldrive***n*** 0 0 X:\\image.img

and:

dsf**i** \\\\.\\Physicaldrive***n*** 0 0 X:\\image.img

is not that much difficult.

Win32diskimager is good as well, but then why you asked?

[https://sourceforge....in32diskimager/](https://sourceforge.net/projects/win32diskimager/ "External link")

![:duff:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

forumNotes.author: hemlatuyda
forumNotes.content:
DSFO is for backing up and DSFI for recovering? How would command that is supposed to copy files back to USB look like, like you posted?

dsf**i** \\\\.\\Physicaldrive***n*** 0 0 X:\\image.img

**Edited by hemlatuyda, 10 July 2017 - 03:38 PM.**

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
RMPrepUSB - Drive-\>File

RMPrepUSB - File-\>Drive

similar to dd but has GUI

or try Passmark [ImageUSB](http://osforensics.com/tools/write-usb-images.html "External link")

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> DSFO is for backing up and DSFI for recovering? How would command that is supposed to copy files back to USB look like, like you posted?
>
> dsf**i** \\\\.\\Physicaldrive***n*** 0 0 X:\\image.img

Yep :smile:, try reading the commands as:

GET (dsf) **o** ut of \\\\.\\Physicaldrive***n***sectors starting from sector 0 up to last sector available (conventionally using 0 for max) and write them to an image X:\\image.img

GET (dsf) **i** nto \\\\.\\Physicaldrive***n***sectors starting from sector 0 up to last sector available (conventionally using 0 for max) getting them from X:\\image.img

In other words, with dsfo the source is the "left side" device or file and the target is the "right side" one, with dsfi the source is the "right side" device or file and the target is the "left side" one.

The alternatives Steve6375 proposed are also excellent, of course, and there are many other ones, here are two more GUI ones:

[http://www.roadkil.n...hp?ProgramID=12](http://www.roadkil.net/program.php?ProgramID=12 "External link")

[http://www.alexpage....-tool/download/](http://www.alexpage.de/usb-image-tool/download/ "External link")

Also DMDE has such a feature, but it is not as simple as the other ones mentioned:

[http://dmde.com/](http://dmde.com/ "External link")

[http://dmde.com/manu...opysectors.html](http://dmde.com/manual/copysectors.html "External link")

![:duff:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

forumNotes.author: Akeo
forumNotes.content:
> But I do need a complete dd-like 1:1 copy because I want it still to be bootable after recovery. I can only use Windows 10 for this. Which tools would be good?

Well, as the author of that utility, I'm obviously a bit biased on this, but [Rufus](https://rufus.akeo.ie "External link") will happily do that for you if you use the Alt-V [cheat mode](https://github.com/pbatard/rufus/wiki/FAQ#Power_keysCheat_modes "External link").

This'll dump your whole USB drive to an **uncompressed** VHD, which you can later use in Rufus (if you select DD-Image), to recreate your drive exactly as it was.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Well, as the author of that utility, I'm obviously a bit biased on this, but [Rufus](https://rufus.akeo.ie "External link") will happily do that for you if you use the Alt-V [cheat mode](https://github.com/pbatard/rufus/wiki/FAQ#Power_keysCheat_modes "External link").
>
> This'll dump your whole USB drive to an **uncompressed** VHD, which you can later use in Rufus (if you select DD-Image), to recreate your drive exactly as it was.

Very good ![:thumbup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbup.gif) , and since it is mentioned, I will add the usual note about a fixed (uncompressed) VHD being nothing but a RAW image with a descriptor sector appended to it :wink:.

![:duff:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/duff.gif)

Wonko

It gets not detected neither in BIOS nor in Windows. ADATA support told me to format it with their special tool that apparently doesn't work. Will probably have to return it.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Try my RMPrepUSB tool. Link in signature.

P.S. If you are trying to boot MBR USB sticks, make sure you disable UEFI Secure Boot and fast boot and enable Legacy\\CSM Mode in the BIOS settings

forumNotes.author: naruto1979
forumNotes.content: I need this because i also formatting computer......Thanks it will me a lot. I'll get back if its working ...

forumNotes.author: Rootman
forumNotes.content:
I use a sync tool, there are many out there. It will not preserve the boot system but will preserve the data on the drive. The main advantage is that it does not have to copy everything, just what's changed. I happen to use Syncback Pro.

I create a folder on my HDD and sync the entire stick to it. I do this weekly because I've corrupted the stick too many times and it takes too long to recreate the stuff. I use it as a backup of many important docs and databases, I also have tons of fairly static stuff - boot ISOs and installation files. The weekly backup assures me I can get it back just about like it was quickly..
